author: A
title: [F5] REFRESH decentralise Catalyst
description: catalyst is currently centralised to a centralised company

assessments.note: The proposal is a draft and there is mention in the description that details will be added. The problem statement is reasonable, but it is not clear how the decentralization relationship of Catalyst can address the challenge, there is no indication of a relationship with distributed decision making. I recommend that the proposer make the idea clearer so that we can understand the proposal and give appropriate feedback.

This idea would address the challenge, but as it stands, it is only a idea, not an executable proposal. Lacking many details as i'll mention in my assessment notes below. Perhaps the proposer could join the NTF-DAO community that is working on a more concrete proposal to solve the same problem.
Interesting idea to move forward decentralised decision making by decentralising catalyst

A decentraliced Project Catalyst sounds beneficial to our community. The thing ist that most of the blockchain projects are a little centralized, but as long as the voting happens on the blockchain the most important part is decentralized.
Further decentralisation is a valid concept although the author needs to expand their idea so that it can be judged on its merits.

Discussing the current state for Catalyst should always be open, even if it is a still being developed. The community could always extract beneficial information and decision making ideas from such a topic. Yet the problem is not additionally described and no plan offered.

There is no relevant information about the proposer's experience or details about the proposal concept and its details. The proposal is just a draft and needs to be further worked on and clarified so that we can give appropriate feedback.

The detailed plan section describes the thoughts of the proposer, but a plan is not presented. No description of how each of the loosely mentioned steps will or could be achieved, no timelines are and no budget breakdown are presented. It's not clear what experience the proposer has to implement this, besides his/hers enthusiasm.

The proposal sounds more like a thought process that an actual idea which can be implemented successfully. There is no information about the proposer or the team behind it. Also there is no budgetplan on how the 20k are used.

Experience and plan are very minimal at this stage so difficult to gauge what the project is about and what it can deliver. There is no way to actually review experience of the author and the plan has not been laid out or budgeted accordingly. If the author were to further engage with the community and perhaps collaborate around details the proposal may be suitable for a future fund.

The self-described experience is very poetic, yet obviously it doesn't offer any relevant information. The proposer needs to add links to his previous experience and a detailed plan, metrics and budget description.

There is not enough information to judge the feasibility and allow the auditability of the proposal (there is no roadmap, metrics, plan and any other relevant details to allow a concrete evaluation). It is not clear how the proposal will improve decision-making. The proposal needs to be worked on so that we can give appropriate feedback.
The proposal lacks most expected details such as milestones and metrics of success that are required to measure progress and effectiveness
No information given on how this would be done this it is not possible to evaluate its feasibility.

The proposal is really short, has no roadmap or clear definition of success. I would recommend to re-do the proposal when it evolves from the idea that it is now to a proposal thats ready to be funded. Good luck!

The proposal is simply lacking in assessable content and this makes it difficult to review. The author has a valid concept but has not really teased out any details that give insight into what is planned. I would recommend scaling down the budget and focussing on delivering something that might add to the knowledge base of decentralisation. Such as a literature review or small scale community views survey.

As stated in the above assessments, the project lacks a detailed description, budget, metrics, expected launch date - all included in the self-assessment checklist. Suggest re-submission to a future fund with the missing information added.

solution: set in motion the decentralisation of catalyst as smart contracts come online
experience: individually, catalyst participant and champion from the beginning. collectively, we're at a bottleneck and need to live what we preach.
